chapters.title: Kinematics
chapters.content: These are the equations of kinematics. x stands for position/distance v is the velocity a is acceleration and t is time elapsed. o and f define initial and final states of distance and velocity. For example in the first equation if my initial velocity vo is 10miles/hr and I accelerate at 60miles/hr^2 for 1 hour then my final velocity vf will be 70m/h(10+60*1).

chapters.title: Newton's Laws
chapters.content: These are newtons 3 laws of motion. The first law states that an object in motion only stops if a force acts on them. A rocket thrown in space will keep traveling forever until some force acts on it like the thrusters or a planets gravity. A car in a road stops because of friction(road or brakes) or gravity at a hill. The second law states that the force on an object is equal to the mass of an object times the acceleration. The third law states that every force exerts an opposite equal force. If you punch a wall you exert a force on the wall and the wall exerts the same force on your fist. If you are standing the floor exerts a force to counter gravity.

chapters.title: Friction
chapters.content: Forces have direction based on the direction the force is being applied. Here a force is being applied to the right. There is also a frictional force that exists because the ground is not smooth and has imperfections. The frictional force always acts in the opposite direction of the applied force. This is what makes moving furniture through the floor hard, because the floor has friction. If there were no friction like at an ice rink it would be much easier to move furniture.

chapters.title: Conservation of Momentum
chapters.content: The conservation of momentum states that momentum can not be destroyed it can only be transfered. In this example two players are running toward each other in opposite directions and collide. The momentum of the linebacker is greater then the momentum of the fullback so the linebacker transfers his momentum to the fullback and that momentum cancels the fullbacks original momentum. Afterwards the players combine for a lower momentum.

chapters.title: Simple Harmonic Motion
chapters.content: This is a spring, a simple example of harmonic motion. A box is attached to a spring in the picture. When the box is displaced from equillibrium(x=0) the spring will exert a force on the box. If the spring is compressed then the spring will push the box to the other direction until the spring is extended, then the spring will pull on the box until the spring is compressed and so on. The box will oscillate back and forth forever unless there is friction on the floor or energy is lost in the spring material.

chapters.title: Gravitational Force
chapters.content: This is newtons gravitational force. It states that two objects with mass will attract and exert a force on each other. The force is equal to a number G multiplied by masss1 and mass2 of the objects and divided by the distance between the objects squared. This is the force that is exerted by the earth when you jump or fall from the sky. Any object with mass will exert this force. There is a gravitational force between two people in a train but because the mass of the two people is so small the effects of the force is bascially negligable. If the 2 people were in empty space eventually after a long time the force would join them like it does when you fall to the earth.

chapters.title: Work
chapters.content: Work is defined as the force exerted on an object multiplied by the distance. When you push a box along the ground you have done work. Work is also defined as energy transfer. You are transfering energy when you are moving the box across the floor.

chapters.title: Kinetic and Potential Energy
chapters.content: Kinetic energy is defined as the energy of motion. Potential energy is energy stored as potential future energy. As the bus climbs the hill it loses kinetic energy and gains potential energy. If a bus is stationary at the top of a hill it has all potential energy and no kinetic energy. Then as the bus travels down the hill is loses potential energy and gains kinetic energy. It is called potential energy becuase if the bus falls down the hill it has the potential to exert all that stored energy.

chapters.title: Conservation of Energy
chapters.content: This is the law of conservation of energy. It states that energy can never be destroyed it can only be transfered perhaps in a different form. The chemical energy in gas is transformed into mechanical energy inside of a car. The light energy of the sun is transfered to chemical energy inside of a plant.

chapters.title: Chaos
chapters.content: Chaotic systems occur when a certain system obtains a level of complexity high enough that predicting its next moves is impossible. If you take a pendulum and swing it back and forth you know that it will mantain that motion until it dies out. But if you attach another pendulum to that pendulum the system become chaotic and it is impossible to determine future motion. This is also know as the butterfly effect. It states that even a butterfly flapping its wings all the way across the globe can cause a chain reaction that causes a storm on the other side of the world.

quiz_questions.question: Why do objects in motion stop?

quiz_answers.answer: Because a force acts on them
Too much force on a surface
Potential energy stored on the surface

quiz_questions.question: What is an example of potential energy?

quiz_answers.answer: A box stationary on the ground
A bus on a steep hill

chapters.title: Curl and Divergence
chapters.content: Electric fields caused by a particle with a positive charge act like the picture on the left. The particle produces a field that diverges from the particle in all directions. If the particle had a negative charge then the arrows would point inward. A magnetic field caused by a magnet is shown in the left. The magnetic field curls around the source otherwise know as current. The direction of current indicates whether the magnetic field will be clockwise or counter clockwise

chapters.title: Charge
chapters.content: Particles may have positive, negative or no charges. A particle with a positive charge will attract a particle with a negative charge. If a particle has no charge like a neutron then it is unaffected by charges and electric fields. In this picture a particle with a negative electric field attracts a particle with a positive electric field

chapters.title: Coulomb's Law
chapters.content: This is coulombs law. It describes a force between two objects. The force is equal to a number constant k multiplied by the total charge of one object q1 and by the total charge of the other object q2 all divided by the distance(r) between them squared. Like charges repel and opposite charges attract.

chapters.title: Gauss's Law
chapters.content: This is Gauss's law it states that if an object is symmetric its charge can be determined by mathematically enclosing it in a symmetric surface like a sphere. The flux of electric field through each tiny area of sphere all summed up is the charge of the inside object

chapters.title: Conductors
chapters.content: This is a conductor. Conductors like metals greatly facilitate the travel of particles within them and as such these particles tend to head toward the surface of the conductor when an electric field is applied. The electric field inside a conductor is 0 since the particles on the surface cancel out the field in all directions measured from inside the conductor

chapters.title: Magnetic Field
chapters.content: This is a magnetic field it is cause by a current which is just a flow of electrons called current. The direction of the magnetic field depends on the the direction of current. If you point your thumb along the direction of current then the magnetic field will be in the direction your fingers curl

chapters.title: Magnetic Monopoles
chapters.content: Magnets always exist in the form of dipoles. A dipole simply means they have a north and south pole and these poles attract each other. There is no way to split apart these north and south poles, they must exist together as one object. If a magnet is cut in half then immediatly a new north and south pole is formed. There is no such thing as a separate north and south magnet. Separated north and south poles are an idea called monopoles but it has never been observed as far as we know they dont exist.

chapters.title: Ferromagnets
chapters.content: Ferromagnets are special types of magnets. For non ferromagnets when a magnetic field is applied the magnetic dipoles inside are aligned and so the object becomes magnetized. When the field is removed the dipoles go back to their original position and the object looses its magnetism. For ferromagnets when a magnetic field is applied and then removed the dipoles inside stay aligned even after the field is removed. These are permanent magnets and can be found sold in stores.

chapters.title: Electromagnetic Waves
chapters.content: Light is an electromagnetic  wave. It is composed of electric and magnetic fields traveling in parallel to each other. Waves have frequency. To visualize frequency imagine a string tied to the wall and you shaking the string up and down creating a wave. The speed of the shaking is the frequency. Depending on the frequency light becomes either visible or ultraviolet or another type in the electromagnetic spectrum.

chapters.title: Maxwell's Equations
chapters.content: These are the famous maxwells equations. They describe electric and magnetic fields and are the equations for light. The first law states that the electric field measured depends on the charge producing the field. The second equation states that magnetic monopoles dont exist magnets must exist in dipoles(north, south poles). The third equation states that an electric current creates a magnetic field and vice versa. The last equation states that a circulating magnetic field is produced by both an electric current and a changing electric field.

quiz_questions.question: What do oppositely charged particles do?
How do you create a magnetic monopole?

quiz_answers.answer: By splitting a magnet in half

chapters.title: Particles
chapters.content: All matter is made of particles. These particles all have energy and speed. A pot and a stove are made up of many particles. When a pot is heated its particles are receiving energy from the stove and so they begin to move faster. The increase of particle movement of an object is the increase in temperature that you see and feel. If you heat ice its particles start to move faster and you produce water. If you heat the water its particles move even faster and you create water vapor.

chapters.title: Heat Transfer
chapters.content: In radiation heat is being transfered in the form of electromagnetic waves(light). In a microwave the microwaves(light) heat up the food inside. Conduction is heat transfer by touch. In a toaster the metal bars are being heated which causes its particles to move rapidly. Since the metal is in contact with bread the metals particles also trasfer energy to the breads particles and so the bread heats up. Convection occurs only in liquids or gases. When a flame is in the room it heats up the surrounding particles and those particles use the energy to rise up and leave behind cooler particles and the process continues.

chapters.title: Thermal Equilibrium
chapters.content: Thermal equilibrium is described as equilibrium in macroscopic properties such as temperature. Energy will flow from the hot box to the cold box until equilibirum is reached and any change in the temperature after that is negligible. The same thing happens with pressure. Equilibrium is reached when the pressure everywhere is equal.

chapters.title: Ideal Gases
chapters.content: This is the ideal gas law it applies to ideal gases. Ideal gases are gases whose particles are do not have any interparticle attractions. This equation gives the relationship between the pressure volume and temperature. Moles are calculated by taking the gases mass and dividing it by the atomic weight of the gas as seen in the periodic table.

chapters.title: 1st Law of Thermodynamics
chapters.content: This is the first law of thermodynamics. It is bascially the conservation of energy. For example the internal energy(U) is the combined energy of all the particles of the substance. If a gas is placed inside a container with a moveable lid then as the gas is heated(Q) the gas increases in energy(U) and does work(W) by moving the lid

chapters.title: Heat Capacity
chapters.content: Heat capacity is the amount of heat required to raise the temperature of a substance by one degree. Different substances have different heat capacities. Metals have lower heat capacities since their particles are close together. Because they are close they can easily transfer energy to one another so it is easy to heat up a metal compared to something like water.

chapters.title: Adiabatic Isolthermal Expansion
chapters.content: Isothermal process is a process in which the temperature of a substance remains constant. When ice is melting its molecules are absorbing energy from heating, however the temperature of ice remains the same until the ice has completly melted. The same thing happens with evaporation. In an adiabatic process the substance does work so it consumes energy but no heating occurs so the substance drops in temperature.

chapters.title: Multiplicity
chapters.content: Multiplicity is defined as the amount of configurations and combinations possible for a given state. With 2 dice there is only one way to create the number 2 so the multiplicity is 1. In thermodynamics the different combinations of particles represent the multiplicities. Since the number of particles of even the smallest object is so large the multiplicity(combinations) of its particles is a huge number. There are a huge way to arrange an objects particles. Liquids have higher multiplicity then solids and gases have higher multiplicity then liquids since multiplicity depends on particle speed.

chapters.title: 2nd Law of Thermodynamics
chapters.content: The second law of thermodynamcis states that the universe will always increase in entropy(disorder). Air inside a balloon is concentrated orderly inside the balloon. When the balloon pops the air escapes and loses the order it had inside the balloon. Things will never achive order unless something forces them to. Dust will accumulate on the floor causing disorder. Unless a person does work and cleans the dust up the dust will continue to accumulate and increase in disorder.

chapters.title: Boltzman Brains
chapters.content: Since particles have random motion they can have many different types of configurations. The second law states that disorder is the most likely outcome but given an enormous amount of time the probability of local order exists. There exists the probability that the particles in space can come together and form a brain out of nowhere which is conscious. Like wise there exists and incredibly small probability that all the particles in a room can come together to form a person or any other ordered combination but the probability of this would require near infinite time and as such this has never been observed.

quiz_questions.question: Why are metals easy to heat?

quiz_answers.answer: Because they have lower heat capacities
Because they obey the 1st law of thermodynamics

quiz_questions.question: What does the 2nd law of thermodynamics state?

quiz_answers.answer: Particles move to a state of low multiplicity

chapters.title: Electrons
chapters.content: Electrons are particles that can usually be found around the nucleous of atoms. Electrons have a very small amount of mass but have no size. Electrons are actually not like the balls in the picture but are points with no volume. All electrons are identical and it is impossible to distinguish one from another. Since electrons and other particles are very small their quantum properties are visible in experiments. Larger objects like animals have basically invisible quantum properties.

chapters.title: Wave Particle Duality
chapters.content: In the double slit experiment light particles were shot from a laser through two openings called slits. Since they were particles they were expected to hit the board and create 2 rectangles like what would happen if you shot paintballs. Instead they created a wave like pattern in the board. This experiment led to the conclusion that light was both a wave and a particle. A wave would mean a kind of cloud of probabilities. All particles share this feature with light.

chapters.title: Schrodinger Equation
chapters.content: This is the famed Schrodinger equation. This equation is solved for the trident like figure called Psi. Psi describes a particle and its quantum properties like position, energy and momentum. Psi is called the wavefunction since a particle is actually a wave. Psi evaluated at different positions is called the eigenstates of a particle. Depending on certain factors a particle(Psi) can have many eigenstates each describing a unique energy amount of the particle. Using an analogy you represent a particle the eigenfunction represents all the USA and the eigenstates represent the 50 states. Depending on which state you are in you will be in a different position and will feel different weather(energy)

chapters.title: Wave Function
chapters.content: This is a graph of the wavefunction Psi of a particle. Since a particle is a wave it does not have a position but a probability of positions. If the graph represented a football field the particle would most likely be found in the center since that is when the probability is the highest. Only when a particle is measured does the probability cloud disappear and a particle becomes a point and not a wave.

chapters.title: Eigenfunctions
chapters.content: This graph represents some particles eigenstates. These eigenstates are represented by Psi evaluated at different energy values shown by the numbers next to Psi. The waves show the probability cloud of a particle.

chapters.title: Superposition
chapters.content: This is schrodingers cat. If the cat was a particle then the concept of alive and dead represent different positions(eigenstates) of a particle. Until you look inside the box the cat is in it is basically both alive and dead to you. The same way until you look at an electron it is actually in multiple positions(eigenstates) represented by a probability cloud.

chapters.title: Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle
chapters.content: This is Heisenberg's uncertainty principle it states that you can never know both the position and momentum of a particle. If you look at a ball rolling on the ground you can tell the balls position and momentum(velocity) at a certain time. The same is not true of particles and tiny objects. You either measure the position or the speed you cant know both.

chapters.title: Tunneling
chapters.content: This is the Quantum Phenomenon of tunneling. In classical physics(Our world) a ball can only roll over a barrier or it is reflected if it hits a hard wall. In the quantum world a particle and actually teleport across a barrier or wall if it has a high enough energy. The higher the energy the higher the probability that an electron launched against a barrier will be able to teleport across.

chapters.title: Quantum Entanglement
chapters.content: Quantum entanglement is one of the most bizzare properties of quantum mechanics baffling even Einstein. There exists some bizzare connection between two particles that seemingly allows one to affect the other instantly even at immense distances. An analogy of this effect would be two coins that are entangled if one is heads the other will always be tails and vice versa. Now if you flip a coin and it lands on heads then when you flip the other coin it will always land on tails. This happens even if the two coins are separated by billions of light years. This property appears to break the crucial speed of light limit but causality is rescued by the fact that no information can be carried by this connection.

chapters.title: Quantum Erasor
chapters.content: The quantum erasor is an improved double slit experiment but it is even more bizzare than the original. The experiment is hard to explain in laymans terms but the main idea is this: if you send particles through the slits while observing them each will go through one slit. If you dont observe the particles they will go through both slits at the same time like if the particle was a wave. Now you cant believe that the particle can go through both openings at the same time so you create a clone after it goes through the slits. Then you measure the clone to see which slit it went through but the universe somehow knows beforehand you will measure the clone so it makes the original particle act as if it was being observed and it goes through only one slit. Then if you add an erasor that erases the information of the clone before you can see it the original particle will act like it went through both openings as if the universe knew you would lose the information.

quiz_questions.question: When does a particle become a point and not a wave?

quiz_answers.answer: When it runs out of energy

quiz_questions.question: What can quantum entanglement be used for?

chapters.title: Speed of Light
chapters.content: Light is the universal speed limit nothing can travel faster than light. Anything with mass can only approach the speed of light but never reach it. Light also travels at the same speed regardless of the observer. If you measure the speed of a ball on a train you would get different results based on if you measured it on the train or outside the train. If you measured from outside you would see the ball going much faster since the train is moving. On the other hand if you measure light you will always measure it to be the same speed even if you are going at 99% the speed of light.

chapters.title: Time Dilation
chapters.content: The faster you travel the more time slows down. Imagine you are looking at a clock and are traveling inside a bus going really fast. The faster you get away from the clock the more time will be needed for the clocks light to reach you. Light rays from the clock will take longer so you will see the clocks hands tick slower than someone next to the clock. Imagine you get on a spaceship traveling really fast and you leave your twin on the earth. After say 40 years have passed on the earth only maybe 10 years will have passed for you since you were traveling so fast and time slows down the faster you go. Your twin back on earth will be much older. This is bascially time travel into the future.

chapters.title: Lenght Contraction
chapters.content: The faster you move the more you contract in length. From an observer at rest if you are moving really fast they will measure you to be shorter than you actually are. On the other hand you will see space shrinking while you stay the same so you will see the observer shirk. Both these points of view are valid.

chapters.title: Energy Mass Equivalence
chapters.content: The faster you move the harder it is to accelerate. The energy of motion is transformed into mass and makes you heavier so more energy is required to accelerate. This is shown in the famous E=mc^2 equation. Light is the universal speed limit and you would need an infinite amount of energy to reach the speed of light. There is no such thing as infinite energy so nothing with mass can travel at the speed of light only massless particles.

chapters.title: Time Travel
chapters.content: If you hypothetically manage to travel at the speed of light then time would stop from your prespective and you would shrink to nothing. Light particles bouncing off objects is the reason why you see everything around you. If you managed to travel faster than light you would go back in time. One way to imagine it is if you are on a spaceship that moves faster than light then you could catch up to light that has already passed you. This means that you would be able to see light you already saw which means you would see events that already happened.

chapters.title: SpaceTime Curvature
chapters.content: Space is made up of three dimensions of space and one dimension of time. Gravity is not really a force. Gravity is actually the bending of the fabric of spacetime. This bending is what makes objects attract like the earth and a person. Imagine you hold a blanket and place a bowling ball in the middle then you place some ball at a corner and it falls toward the center. The bending of the fabric is what makes the ball fall toward the bowling ball at the center. This is bascially what gravity is. The amount of curvature depends on the mass of the object.

chapters.title: Einstein's Field Equations
chapters.content: This is einsteins field equations. It relates the curvature of spacetime with the properites of matter like energy and momentum. On the left you have the ricci tensor, ricci constant and the metric tensor which describe spacetime. On the right you have einsteins gravitational constant and the stress energy tensor which describe properties of matter.

chapters.title: Black Holes
chapters.content: Black holes are special objects predicted by einsteins equaitons of general relativity. These objects are so massive and heavy that they curve spacetime to a point where the bottom is an infinitesimal singularity. The bending of space is so great that no even light can escape the pull. If you pass the event horizon of a black hole there is no turning back you will fall and forever be trapped inside. Inside the black hole time becomes space and space becomes time.

chapters.title: Gravitational Waves
chapters.content: Gravitational waves are ripples through spacetime. Gravitational waves were predicted by einstein and were recently proved to exist. The gravitaional waves measured came from two distant colliding black holes and were very difficult to measure since they are very faint.

chapters.title: Hawking Radiation
chapters.content: Hawking radiation is the process of a black hole losing its energy. It is theorized that over time because of quantum events black holes emit radiation in the form of virtual particles. This causes the black holes to lose their mas and energy over time. This process is however incredibly slow and it would take a googol amount of years for a supermassive black hole to disintegrate. At the end of the universe black holes will be the last remaining objects for many many years.

quiz_answers.answer: Traveling at the speed of light

quiz_questions.question: What happens inside a black hole?

quiz_answers.answer: The ricci tensor predicts mass energy convergence
